title: Congress Passes Bill To Avert Government Shutdown
teaser: The stopgap spending bill would keep the government open until mid-January and extend funding for the Children's Health Insurance Program through March. In addition to most Republicans, about a dozen House Democrats and several Senate Democrats also voted for the bill.

title: 'We'll Probably Move On': McConnell Doesn't See Obamacare Repeal Returning In 2018
teaser: With an even slimmer Republican majority in the Senate in 2018, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell doesn't see much of a point in repeating health care efforts that failed this year.

title: Pence Makes His First Trip To Afghanistan As Vice President
teaser: The previously unannounced visit comes four months after President Trump unveiled a new strategy for the United States' role in Afghanistan.

title: Rounding Up Reindeer: Zoo Prepares To Evacuate As Fire Burns Close
teaser: As the massive Thomas Fire burs in California, the Santa Barbara Zoo's elaborate evacuation plan involves 150 species, tranquilizers and maybe even throwing a towel over an alligator's head.

title: How To Host A Hygge Holiday Party: Get Cozy, Embrace Imperfection
teaser: The Nordic concept of hygge loosely translates to a feeling of coziness, and for many hosts, it's the perfect antidote to a high-stress year and the typical fussiness associated with holiday parties.

title: Cities Across The U.S. Honor 'Homeless Persons' Memorial Day'
teaser: On Thursday — the longest night of the year — organizations across the country gathered to remember the often-overlooked deaths of people who had no place to go.

title: Jury Finds First Batch Of Inauguration Protesters Not Guilty Of Riot Charges
teaser: More than 180 demonstrators face trial over protests on Jan. 20. The first six defendants have been found not guilty in a verdict that could have implications for prosecutors' strategies.

title: Finding A Legal Loophole, Memphis Takes Down Its Confederate Statues
teaser: To skirt a state law prohibiting the monuments' removal, the city sold two of its parks to a new nonprofit. "In all of my life in Memphis, I've never seen such solidarity," said Mayor Jim Strickland.

title: Restaurant Workers Strike At Chicago's O'Hare Airport
teaser: Employees whose contract expired in August picketed on a busy holiday travel day. They demanded better wages and health care from food service operator HMSHost which reported no disruption.

title: The Top Stories On NPR.org In 2017
teaser: The stories that NPR's readers embraced range from news of President Trump's first year in Washington to warnings about living in an "underslept state" and "What Living On $100,000 A Year Looks Like."

title: In Special Election, Voters In Catalonia Put Pro-Independence Leaders Back In Power
teaser: Catalonia declared independence in October, only to see Madrid fire its leaders and strip their power. Tensions show no sign of fading away, with pro-secessionist groups once again in control.

title: 'The Post': Pentagon Papers Put The Press Under Pressure
teaser: Steven Spielberg's account of the publication of the Pentagon Papers in 1971 is melodrama, but Bob Mondello says it's urgent — and effective.

title: U.N. Votes Overwhelmingly To Condemn U.S. Decision On Jerusalem
teaser: By a 128-9 vote, the General Assembly rejected a U.S. decree that recognized the disputed city as Israel's capital. "The United States will remember this day," Ambassador Nikki Haley warned.

title: Philadelphia Horse-Drawn Carriage Company Shuts Down After Abuse Allegations
teaser: City inspectors found violations of building codes and animal welfare laws. The horses will be sent to a sanctuary. A second company still offers carriage rides.

title: These Are The Winners In The Game Of Foreign Policy For 2017
teaser: NPR foreign correspondents weigh in on the politicians and political forces that helped shape the world in 2017.

title: U.N. Investigator On Extreme Poverty Issues A Grim Report — On The U.S.
teaser: Philip Alston, who was appointed as a United Nations special rapporteur, undertook his fact-finding mission with a series of questions: Are those in poverty able to live with dignity? And what does a government do to protect those who are most vulnerable?

title: Another Famous Conductor, Charles Dutoit, Accused Of Sexual Assault
teaser: Charles Dutoit has been accused by four women of sexual assault in incidents that allegedly occurred between 1985 and 2010.

title: Bombs In Baby Food Jars Are Just One Part of Colombia's Land Mine Problem
teaser: Now that the rebels and the government have reached a peace deal, the slow process of de-mining is underway.

title: For Many Caribbean Immigrants, It Wouldn't Be Christmas Without Black Cake
teaser: Many in New York's large Caribbean diaspora cling to the rich, molasses-spiced cake filled with drunken dried fruits. It takes months to prepare and is central to festivities throughout the islands.

title: The Shortest Days Of The Year, And The Worst Traffic Of The Season
teaser: In some cities, the worst traffic for this holiday season hit Wednesday afternoon. In others, the back-up is about to start, as Thursday afternoon's commuters mix with Christmas travelers.

title: David Sedaris, Ira Glass And 25 Years Of 'Santaland Diaries'
teaser: Writer David Sedaris talks about the 25th anniversary of the radio piece that launched his career. Ira Glass, who produced it for Morning Edition, knew when he recorded it that it was special.

title: Idaho Leads U.S. As Fastest Growing State, Census Bureau Reports
teaser: The population of Idaho increased by 2.2 percent, making it the fastest growing state in the nation. Three other western states were just behind it: Nevada, Utah and Washington.

title: Life Expectancy Drops Again As Opioid Deaths Surge In U.S.
teaser: The opioid epidemic caused U.S. life expectancy to fall for the second year in a row, marking the first time that has happened since the early 1960s. Death rates also continued to rise.
